description: From Middle English plasch, plasche, from Old English plæsċ (“pool, puddle”). Cognate with Dutch plas (“pool, watering hole”). Related also to West Frisian plaskje (“to splash, splatter”), Dutch plassen (“to splash, splatter”), German platschen (“to splash”).

entries.meaning: (UK, dialectal) A small pool of standing water; a puddle.
examples: Hereof Aesop framed the Fable of the two Frogs that consulted together in time of drowth (when many plashes that they had repayred to were dry) what was to be done.

entries.meaning: A splash, or the sound made by a splash.
examples: Presently a gondola passed along the canal with its slow rhythmical plash, and as we listened we watched it in silence.
[...] down burst torrents of thick rain and muddied us to the skin. The valley began to run in plashes of water, and Dakhil-Allah urged us across it quickly. [...]

verbs.description: plash (third-person singular simple present plashes, present participle plashing, simple past and past participle plashed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To splash or sprinkle with colouring matter.
examples: to plash a wall in imitation of granite

description: From Middle English *plasshen, *plaisshen, *plesshen, from Old French plaissier, plessier (“to bend”). For the noun, compare Middle English plaisshes (“hedges forming an enclosure, palisade of hedges or wattles”). Compare also pleach.

entries.meaning: The branch of a tree partly cut or bent, and bound to, or intertwined with, other branches.

verbs.description: plash (third-person singular simple present plashes, present participle plashing, simple past and past participle plashed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cut partly, or to bend and intertwine the branches of.
(transitive) To bend down a bough (in order to pick fruit from it).
